titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Fern and Hersh Cohen Print Collection
1891-1948
PR 466
titlestmt.author: Marybeth Kavanagh

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-05-15 11:29:56 -0400.

did.unittitle: Fern and Hersh Cohen Print Collection
did.abstract: Approximately 200 works on paper by American artists, dating from 1891-1948, from the collection of Fern and Hersh Cohen. The majority of the prints depict various aspects of Depression era American life.
did.physloc: Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The prints are listed alphabetically by artist.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The prints in this collection were amassed over a period of more than 40 years by Hersh Cohen, an investment manager, and his wife Fern Cohen, a school librarian. The Cohens have focused on collecting prints by American artists created between 1900 and World War II, with an emphasis on the Depression era.

A number of the prints were created under the auspices of the Works Progress Administration (WPA, renamed the Work Projects Administration in 1939), a New Deal government agency created by President Roosevelt that hired millions of Americans to execute public works and community service projects. While many WPA workers built roads, bridges, and other infrastructure, some divisions assigned people to work in the arts. The WPA Federal Art Project (FAP) was established in 1935 to create employment for artists during the Great Depression. The Graphic Arts Division of the program, which emphasized block printing and lithography, among other printmaking techniques, employed more than 700 artists across 36 American cities, many of whom used their work to address social justice issues.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Fern and Hersh Cohen, 2023.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The collection should be cited as: Fern and Hersh Cohen Print Collection, PR 466, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, New-York Historical Society.
Credit Line for exhibitions should read: Fern and Hersh Cohen Print Collection.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Archivist Marybeth Kavanagh arranged and described this collection in May 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection comprises approximately 200 works on paper by American artists, dating from 1891-1948. The majority of the prints depict facets of American life during the era of the Great Depression, a time of social upheaval and economic hardship for many. Included are scenes of workers at their jobs; strikes; homelessness; as well as people gathered on stoops, in bars, and at various amusements. Many of the prints are New York City views.

The container list includes the artist and title of all prints in the collection. Scope notes include information about printmaking technique and dimensions, as well as the presence of a WPA stamp. Dates, titles, and dimensions are based on information received from the donors.
